title: 108_hr1874
content: The Act may be cited as the "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" and includes a demonstration project to clarify the definition of homebound. The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" includes a demonstration project where medicare beneficiaries with chronic conditions can receive home health services if certified as permanently homebound by a physician. The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" establishes a demonstration project for medicare beneficiaries with chronic conditions who are permanently homebound and require assistance to leave their homes. The Secretary will collect data on the project's quality of care, patient outcomes, and any additional costs to the medicare program. Reports will be submitted to Congress, and the Secretary has waiver authority to conduct demonstration projects. The Secretary has the authority to conduct demonstration projects for medicare beneficiaries with chronic conditions who are permanently homebound. The project will collect data on quality of care, patient outcomes, and costs to the medicare program. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the project's costs. The term "beneficiary" refers to an individual entitled to benefits under parts A and B of the Social Security Act. "Home health services" are defined as in section 1861(m) of the Act. "Activities of daily living" include eating, toileting, transferring, bathing, and dressing. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 3. CLARIFICATION OF THE DEFINITION OF HOMEBOUND FOR ELIGIBILITY FOR HOME HEALTH SERVICES UNDER MEDICARE. The text clarifies the definition of being 'confined to his home' for eligibility for home health services under Medicare for individuals with permanent and severe conditions. It specifies the criteria for individuals requiring assistance with daily activities and home health services to be considered homebound. The text clarifies the definition of being 'confined to his home' for eligibility for home health services under Medicare for individuals with permanent and severe conditions. It specifies the criteria for individuals requiring assistance with daily activities and home health services to be considered homebound. The amendments made by subsection (a) regarding the provision of home health services under the Medicare program will become effective based on the results of a demonstration project to be reported to Congress by the Secretary of Health and Human Services by December 1, 2006. If the project shows adverse effects or unreasonable increase in expenditures, the project will be discontinued, and the amendments will become effective on January 1, 2007. The text clarifies eligibility criteria for home health services under Medicare for individuals with permanent and severe conditions. It includes specific data on increased expenditures directly attributable to the clarification and recommendations to exempt disabled homebound beneficiaries from restrictions on absences from home. Technical amendments are made to sections of the Social Security Act. Technical amendments are made to sections of the Social Security Act, including amending sections 1814(a) and 1835(a) by adjusting eligibility criteria for home health services under Medicare.
